question: Question_01_(c)
statement:
\emph{Multiple Choice Question: Exactly ONE of the answers provided is
correct. There is no partial credit in this question.}

The expression

\begin{align*}\displaystyle S_3 = 1+x^3+\frac{x^6}2\end{align*} is the first three terms of a
Taylor series for:

\begin{align*} \textit{i. }\quad &\sin(x^3)\\
\textit{ii. }\quad &\cos(x^{\frac32})\\
\textit{iii. }\quad &\cos(x)\\
\textit{iv. }\quad &\cos(x^3)\\
\textit{v. }\quad &e^{x^3} \end{align*}
sols:
A clever way of doing this problem is to consider the following:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $S_3(0) = 1$, hence the candidate function needs to also satisfy this
  condition. Since $\sin(0) = 0 \not= 1$, choice \emph{i.} can be
  eliminated.
\item
  $S_3$ is increasing for small positive values of \emph{x}, since, for
  small \emph{x}, the term \emph{x\textsuperscript{3}} dominates. In
  particular, $S_3(x) > 1$ for small positive values of \emph{x}. But
  since the cosine is decreasing for small positive values of \emph{x},
  and can also never be more than \emph{1}, the choices \emph{ii},
  \emph{iii}, and \emph{iv} can all be eliminated.
\item
  This only leaves \emph{v.} Notice that this choice makes
  sense\begin{align*}e^0 = 0,\end{align*} and $e^{x^3}$ is increasing.
\end{itemize}
hints: Recall the Taylor series expansion for $\sin(x)$, $\cos(x)$, and $e^x$.
